awd_titl_txt: Conference: 2024 Foundations of Molecular Modeling and Simulation Conference (FOMMS)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded by contributions from the Chemical Theory, Models, and Computational Methods program of the Division of Chemistry, the Interfacial Engineering and Process Systems, Reaction Engineering, and Molecular Thermodynamics programs of the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Systems and the Condensed Matter and Materials Theory program of the Division of Materials Research. This grant will make it possible for over 30 graduate students and postdocs and 10 early career researchers to attend the 90th triennial conference on the Foundations of Molecular Modeling and Simulation (FOMMS 2024) to be held in Snowbird, UT from July 28 to August 1, 2024. Molecular-level modeling and simulation are ubiquitous tools for advancing science and engineering in applications ranging from the design of new materials to understanding how drug molecules interact with protein receptors in the body. The FOMMS conference series was initiated in 2000 to foster interaction among academic, national laboratory, and industrial molecular researchers developing and applying molecular-based computational methods. FOMMS 2024 will feature 15 plenary speakers, one keynote speaker, a FOMMS Metal Lecture, workshops with an educational focus, and two poster sessions. With no parallel sessions, the meeting structure is designed to encourage formal and informal interactions between established and early career researchers and promote mentoring of the latter. The diverse and international selection of invited speakers strikes a balance between industrial and academic researchers. 

The theme of FOMMS 2024 is “Molecular Modeling Across Scales”, recognizing the key role connecting disparate length and time scales plays in making prediction and using physics-based modeling to understand complex systems. Participants include experts from molecular simulations, proteins and biological systems, acceleration algorithms, soft materials and complex fluid, simulation-based engineering & science, and quantum computing and emerging architectures for modeling and simulation, computational quantum chemistry, statistical mechanics, molecular simulation and theory, and continuum and engineering process simulation. The conference will serve as a venue to bring together experts from different fields to spur new discussions and seed collaborations that will lead to innovative applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Conference: 2024 Foundations of Molecular Modeling and Simulation Conference (FOMMS)

Project Outcomes Report
Award 2416473

 

The 2024 Foundations of Molecular Modeling and Simulation Conference (FOMMS) took place July 28 – August 1 in Snowbird, Utah. FOMMS showcases new developments and applications of computational quantum chemistry, statistical mechanics, molecular simulation and theory, and continuum and engineering process simulation.

Conference sessions included:

  • Machine Learning & AI in Molecular Modeling & Simulation
  • Best Practices for Publishing
  • Catalysis & Reaction Engineering
  • Advances in Materials Simulations
  • Advances in Molecular Modeling & Simulation
  • Careers in Molecular Modeling & Simulation
  • Biomolecular Simulations
  • Crystallization
  • Use of Large Language Models in Molecular Simulation

FOMMS gathered 182 attendees, which is the largest instance of the conference series. The meeting focused on creating collaborations by bringing experts from across the globe to a venue that enables networking and establishing international collaborations. This leads to joint research projects and interdisciplinary initiatives. Additionally, FOMMS included professional development opportunities, including sessions focused on skills development, career advice and navigating academic and industry careers.

The conference prioritizes high quality technical content, by gathering experts in the field as organizers. The quality of the program is reflected in the Chairs, Programming Committee and Plenary Speakers.

Chair

  • Jim Pfaendtner, N.C. State

Co-Chairs

  • Shikha Nangia, Syracuse University
  • Pieter in ‘t Veld, BASF

Programming Committee

  • Andrew Ferguson, University of Chicago
  • Hanyu Gao, HKUST
  • Lars Grabow, University of Houston
  • Heather Kulik, MIT
  • Rebecca Lindsey, University of Michigan
  • Andres Mejia, University de Concepcion
  • Valeria Molinero, University of Utah
  • Erich Muller, Imperial College London
  • Nisanth Nair, IIT Kanpur
  • Jed Pitera, IBM
  • Sapna Sarupria, University of Minnesota
  • Jindal Shah, Oklahoma State University
  • Scott Shell, UC Santa Barbara
  • Michael Shirts, University of Colorado, Boulder
  • Tom Truskett, University of Texas
  • Lourdes Vega, Khalifa University
  • Christopher Wilmer, University of Pittsburgh

Plenary Speakers

  • Nathan Baker, Microsoft
  • Paulette Clancy, Johns Hopkins University
  • Julia Deshemuchadse, Cornell University
  • Rachel Getman, Ohio State University
  • Olexandr Isayev, Carnegie Mellon
  • Jianwen Jiang, National University of Singapore
  • Jeetain Mittal, Texas A&M
  • Sukrit Mukhopadhyay, Dow
  • Erik Santiso, NC State
  • Tamar Schlick, New York University
  • Shaama Sharada, University of Southern California
  • Birgit Strodel, University of Dusseldorf
  • Pratyush Tiwary, University of Maryland
  • Mark Tuckerman, New York University
  • Thijs Vlugt, TU Delft
  • Tiffany Walsh, Deakin University

The goal of this grant was to provide registration support to students, post-docs and early career faculty working at U.S. universities. People just starting their careers often do not have the financial resources to participate in conferences. However, it is arguably most important for these groups to attend conferences, which offer valuable learning, networking and career development opportunities. The connections and knowledge gained by early career attendees at conferences puts the field in a strong position to continue advancing into the future.

FOMMS successfully achieved the goal of this grant, providing support to 35 graduate students and post-docs. Supported attendees also represented a broad geographical range, joining FOMMS from the following states:

  • Alabama
  • California
  • Colorado
  • Florida
  • Idaho
  • Illinois
  • Indiana
  • Maryland
  • Massachusetts
  • Michigan
  • New Jersey
  • New York
  • North Carolina
  • Pennsylvania
  • Texas
  • Utah
  • Wyoming
